title: Before 1 July 2020, will SpaceX launch its first crewed mission into orbit?

Lot's of articles out today about weather and the chance of flying, but it looks like the probabilities for aborting launch remain the same, with 40% chance of abort today and 30% chance of abort on their fallback date. Both of these would have to come true for this question to be a "No". Assuming both are independent, we have 12% chance that neither days work out due to weather. Assuming they would still be motivated and willing to reschedule sometime in June, and satisfy this forecast, I'll cut the percentage in half.

SpaceX’s Falcon 9 and Crew Dragon spacecraft are now set to fly with NASA astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken onboard, making a trip to the International Space Station, and both the agency and SpaceX announced today that they have officially passed the final flight readiness review, meaning everything is now a ‘go’ for launch.

•	SpaceX on Monday confirmed that its next launch will be Demo-2, currently scheduled for May 27.
•	The mission will be the first time the company launches people, as the SpaceX rocket and spacecraft will send two NASA astronauts to the International Space Station.
•	NASA astronauts Bob Behnken and Doug Hurley are set to liftoff at 4:32 p.m. EDT at Kennedy Space Center in Florida. SpaceX is just nine days away from the most significant launch in the history of Elon Musk’s company. The company confirmed on Monday that its next launch will be Demo-2, currently scheduled for May 27. The mission will see two NASA astronauts strap in to SpaceX’s Crew Dragon capsule and head for the International Space Station. SpaceX had planned to launch another batch of its Starlink satellites this week. But, due to a coming tropical storm, the company decided to delay the satellite mission and instead focus on Demo-2.

NASA will provide coverage of the upcoming prelaunch and launch activities for the agency’s SpaceX Demo-2 test flight with NASA astronauts Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley to the International Space Station. These activities are a part of NASA’s Commercial Crew Program, which is working with the U.S. aerospace industry to launch astronauts on American rockets and spacecraft from American soil for the first time since 2011. NASA and SpaceX are targeting 4:32 p.m. EDT Wednesday, May 27, for the launch of the Demo-2 flight, which will be the first time a commercially built and operated American rocket and spacecraft will carry humans to the space station. The launch, as well as other activities leading up to the launch, will air live on NASA Television and the agency’s website. The SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft will launch on a Falcon 9 rocket from historic Launch Complex 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. The Crew Dragon is scheduled to dock to the space station at 11:29 a.m. Thursday, May 28. NASA Website. (2020). NASA to Provide Coverage of SpaceX Commercial Crew Test Flight with Astronauts. NASA Humans in Space. May 1, 2020. Retrieved from
https://www.nasa.gov/press-release/nasa-to-provide-coverage-of-spacex-commercial-crew-test-flight-with-astronauts \
/SpaceX to Bring Crew to Short-Staffed Space Station for Longer Stay \
What was intended as a two-week test flight of SpaceX’s new astronaut-carrying capsule will now be a mission planned to last more than a month to help a short-handed crew aboard the International Space Station. The launch of SpaceX’s Crew Dragon capsule, carrying two NASA astronauts, Douglas G. Hurley and Robert L. Behnken, is scheduled for May 27 from Kennedy Space Center in Florida. It would arrive at the space station the following day.
/

"We are aware of a few technical items that remain to be more fully understood before the event occurs, but the path forward appears feasible," ASAP Chair Patricia Sanders said Thursday during a public (though phone-only) meeting of the panel, which reports to both NASA and Congress. Though Sanders didn't identify the technical items, she may have been referring to outstanding work related to Crew Dragon's parachute system and SpaceX's Falcon 9 rocket, which will launch Demo-2. SpaceX has aced a series of trials recently with the capsule's revamped chute design, but the company still has a drop test on the docket for early May.  One of the nine Merlin engines that power the Falcon 9's first stage suffered a failure during a March launch of 60 SpaceX Starlink internet satellites. Though the anomaly did not unduly affect that mission — the Falcon 9 is designed to overcome such issues — NASA officials have said they want an investigation into the incident completed before Demo-2 lifts off. Clark, S. (2020). Bridenstine says Crew Dragon could launch with astronauts at end of May. Space flight Now. April 13, 2020. Retrieved from
https://spaceflightnow.com/2020/04/13/bridenstine-says-crew-dragon-could-launch-with-astronauts-at-end-of-may/ NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine says he is “fairly confident” that astronauts can fly to the International Space Station aboard SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spaceship at the end of May or early June, pending final parachute tests, data reviews and a training schedule that can escape major impacts from the coronavirus pandemic. An investigation into an engine failure on the most recent launch of SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket — the same design that will launch the Crew Dragon astronauts — is also expected to be completed in short order, Bridenstine said. “I think we’re really good shape,” Bridenstine said in an interview Thursday. “I’m fairly confident that we can launch at the end of May. If we do slip, it’ll probably be into June. It won’t be much.” NASA astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken are training for the Crew Dragon test flight, which will be the first mission to launch astronauts into Earth orbit from U.S. soil since the retirement of the space shuttle in July 2011. The astronauts will take off from pad 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center and dock with the space station a day or two later.

I am afraid adverse events and covid-19 will conspire to prevent this launch in May/June, too many fires to put out and too many constraints to action.

Due to the recent COVID-19 outbreak, SpaceX is unlikely to launch by July.  The COVID virus is likely to persist for the next couple of months if not up to a year (https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2020/03/how-will-coronavirus-end/608719/). SpaceX and NASA have since delayed launches that were scheduled for late this month (https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/24/spacex-encounters-first-launch-delay-due-to-coronavirus/). However, as of March 18th NASA has invited the media to attend the launch event in May. NASA claims to be monitoring the event but since a week ago, COVID-19 has spread rapidly in the United States, from 4,000 cases on March 16th to 60,000 cases on the 25th. Additionally, Space X itself has been hit by the COVID virus (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/24/spacex-one-medical-employees-in-hawthorne-test-positive-for-covid-19.html). In non-COVID related news, the last test before sending humans into space aboard SpaceX rockets encountered a critical engine malfunction during a test (https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/18/spacexs-latest-starlink-launch-included-an-unforeseen-engine-issue/). The failure will require a thorough investigation, which must be completed before the human boarded launch. With external and internal factors piling up, I give this launch a 10% chance of occurring by 1 July 2020.
Due the the COVID-19 virus' rapid spread. I believe that SpaceX will postpone the launch to ensure that the virus has subsided before possibly putting an infected person into space.
Coronavirus will delay the intermediate milestones for testing and the results will likely compound.

Currently, SpaceX is still interested in launching their first crewed mission into orbit. Despite COVD-19 stopping major operations, SpaceX has not made any plans to postpone their mission. It took six years to develop and it is projected to launch in mid to late May. I believe that the world is underestimating COVD-19, especially the United States. With all of the uncertainties, it is very likely that the launch will be postponed to probably in the fall. But, I think the decision to postpone will be very difficult because NASA has been talking about this launch for a very long time. Currently, workers at NASA have been told to work from home and Elon Musk has told workers to not come into work if they are feeling sick, in a way that shows he is downplaying the severity of the virus. The NASA administrator has stated that the agency will keep on moving with important space missions. With all of these uncertainties, it seems that NASA and SpaceX do not know what is the best course of actions, therefore it is likely that the launch will not occur before July. 
https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/19/21186511/spacex-nasa-crew-dragon-astronauts-launch-may-international-space-station

An upcoming launch has been delayed owing to Covid-19 (https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/24/spacex-encounters-first-launch-delay-due-to-coronavirus/).  Some SpaceX employees have been sent home because of Covid-19 (https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/24/spacex-one-medical-employees-in-hawthorne-test-positive-for-covid-19.html).

Words mean nothing as reality bites, it bites hard. Talented people are required to make this happen. People have consistently underestimated the extent of the epidemic in their region to their peril. All systems may be go, but the virus may get there first. This forecast is based on NO KNOWLEGE of the specific situation.
Although the launch was initially scheduled for May, Kennedy Space Center and SpaceX employees are currently teleworking. This will likely cause delays, pushing back the launch until after July.

Space travel is becoming an essential part of the U.S. and global economy as well as an essential part of the private industry. SpaceX is a private company that is investing a lot into space travel and without the presence of the COVID-19 virus, the July 1st deadline for SpaceX to launch the first crewed mission into orbit would be completely feasible. According to a recently published article, SpaceX is taking action to limit the impact of the virus and therefore state that they are confident that their launch schedules would not be impacted. Although the company is confident, there are many uncertainties surrounding the virus, its impact on the economy, and how SpaceX will be impacted by it. However, I chose a percentage that was slightly higher because, as of today, President Trump announced that he would like to have the economy back up and running within two weeks (15-day plan) rather than in months. Because of that, there is now a slightly higher chance (75%) that SpaceX will not be severely impacted by the Coronavirus and therefore may meet its July 1st launch date. 
 https://www.space.com/space-industry-coronavirus-spacex-1st-crewed-launch.html

I want to look at the probability that SpaceX will launch a crewed mission, given the fact that coronavirus has delayed launches as reported by tech crunch (https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/24/spacex-encounters-first-launch-delay-due-to-coronavirus/). According to Bayes' Theorem, the probability of SpaceX failing to launch given the pandemic [P(a/b)] is equal to the probability that the coronavirus will delay a space organization's ability to operate [P(b/a)] times the probability of failing to launch a crewed orbit into space [P(a)] divided by the probability of a non-essential organization being affected by coronavirus [P(b)].  If the coronavirus was not a big deal right now, I would assume that it would take far longer than seven months for any organization to plan, construct and test a crewed capsule. Thus, while you could argue that there would have been a higher probability for SpaceX to launch its first crewed mission by July 2021, I'm going to give them a very optimistic 15% shot at BEST to launch a crewed mission under normal circumstances. This means that there is an 85% chance that SpaceX would fail to launch its first crewed mission by July 2020, giving us the P(a).   P(b), or the probability of non-essential organization being affected by Coronavirus will be measure using the map provided in the chart from here (https://www.cleveland.com/metro/2020/03/50-states-of-coronavirus-how-every-state-in-the-us-has-responded-to-the-pandemic.html) Since there are 50 states, meaning that every state is worth 2 percentage points, I decided that anything labelled red increases probability by 2% and orange increases probability by 1. With this logic, there is a 34% of a non-essential organization being affected by coronavirus. P(b/a) is the probability that COVID-19 will delay a space organization's ability to operate. The best way to understand this is by looking at where the launch facilities are and how badly affected they are. Looking at Space X's about page (https://www.spacex.com/about) its launch facilities are in Texas, California and Florida. Of these states, only California has been badly affected so far, meaning that this is a 33% chance of delay. Thus, by plugging this information into Bayes Theorem, we find that the probability of SpaceX failing to launch "Crew Dragon" given the coronavirus pandemic [P(a/b)] = (.33x.15)/.34 or an 82.5%, rounded up to 83%, chance of SpaceX failing to launch its first crewed mission by the July 2020 deadline. Since the question asks the likelihood of its success, I simply have to subtract 83% from 100%, giving us the final answer of 17%.

The SpaceX Demo-2 mission is currently scheduled to launch on 7 may, 2020, out of Cape Canaveral Air Station in Brevard county, Florida [1]. In order to assess the possibility of this mission launching before 1 July 2020, multiple factors need to be considered. First and foremost is the status of the launch site and the current and future impact of the COVID-19 spread. Currently, Brevard county has reported its first presumptive COVID-19 infection [2]. It seems likely that there will be an increase in COVID-19 infections across florida, and Brevard county and Gov DeSantis just ordered all bars and nightclubs closed and imposed crows limits at beaches and restaurants [3]. Along with Brevard county, we must look at the response that Cape Canaveral Air Force Station is taking. Currently, they are still conducting launch operations, but they have gone to HPCON BRAVO [4], which means all Service members should avoid contact with others, avoid unnecessary travel, have 14 days worth of supplies, and prepare for travel restrictions and cancellations of group events [5]. the 45th Space Wing is meeting today to discuss launch plans in regards to the COVID-19 outbreak [6]. Further, the Secretary of Defense has placed strict travel restrictions on DoD members and their families that continues through 11 May 2020 [7]. This is important because it shows that the US military believes this outbreak will last longer than 2-4 weeks. The next step is to analyze is the SpaceX response to the COVID-19 outbreak. 6 days ago the company's President stated that they remain optimistic about the launch occurring in May [8]. However, there have not been any updates (in regards to the launch) since that one and much has chanced in the world in the last 6 days. One concern that could impact the timing of the launch is the health of the two astronauts that will be manning the mission. NASA does institute a 14-day health quarantine for any space travelers before they launch and both astronauts are currently training as if the mission will occur in May [9]. However, if the mission is unable to launch in May, due to COVID-19 restrictions, there would still be time for the launch to occur before 1 July 2020. it is important to note that President Trump did state that effects from COVID-19 could impact the United States through the July/August time frame [10]. Taking into consideration the current restrictions and future restrictions, it seems likely that the Air Force, Space Force, NASA and SpaceX will have protocols in place to ensure a launch occurs. Unless something unexpected happens, there should be a large enough window between 7 May 20 and 1 July 20 for SpaceX to launch its mission. Therefore, I assess that there is an 88% possibility that SpaceX will launch its crewed mission before 1 July 2020.  This prediction will most likely change weekly as the impacts of COVID-19 become more clear. Please point out/correct any incorrect statements/analysis/assessments I have made. https://thenextweb.com/space/2020/02/10/musks-spacex-will-likely-launch-first-manned-flight-near-may-7/ I don't see any issue with this SpaceX launch being delayed as a result of any technological or logistical issues. In early February, Eric Berger of Art Technica announced via Twitter that SpaceX's official expected launch date has been scheduled for May 7, and CEO Elon Musk has stated that it's possible this date could be moved up even sooner into April. However, with the recent outbreak of the COVID-19 coronavirus in the United States, it seems unlikely that this date will hold due to concerns regarding the health and safety of SpaceX employees, especially its astronauts. Though I do not envision the May 7 launch date holding up, I think that a date sometime in June is certainly feasible as Musk is known for keeping a tight schedule and the majority of the coronavirus crisis will have blown over by July 1. This does not mean that a date in July or later could be selected, but due to SpaceX's prior history of keeping launches running in a timely manner, it is more likely than not that this manned launch will occur before July 1, 2020.

Just 2 days ago on March 6, 2020 SpaceX successfully launched its Falcon 9 rocket on the company’s 20th cargo mission to the International Space Station, and had their 50th overall rocket landing for the company. This routine launch was significant because it is “the final resupply mission for NASA under SpaceX’s original contract with the space agency”. Now SpaceX will begin its work with the new Dragon 2 capsule which will be used to send people to the international space station. I suggest a 1% chance SpaceX will launch before July 1st this year, which is significantly lower than my previous prediction. Why? 
Axiom Space, “a company with ambitions to develop a private space station, announced March 5 that it has signed a contract with SpaceX for a commercial Crew Dragon mission to the International Space Station. Axiom said the mission, scheduled for launch no earlier than the second half of 2021, will carry one Axiom professional astronaut and three private astronauts to the ISS. The mission will last 10 days, including eight at the station and two in transit. The company did not disclose terms of the deal, nor pricing for the individual private astronauts. The flight announcement comes as Axiom works to raise outside investment. Suffredini said in that earlier interview that the company is in the process of raising a Series A funding round on the order of $100 million, which it hopes to close by the beginning of summer.
The contract is the second deal for a commercial Crew Dragon mission announced in less than a month. Space Adventures announced Feb. 18 it had an agreement for a Crew Dragon mission launching between late 2021 and the middle of 2022. That flight, carrying four private astronauts, will not go to the ISS but instead fly in an orbit more than twice as high as the station. “Thanks to Axiom and their support from NASA, privately crewed missions will have unprecedented access to the space station, furthering the commercialization of space and helping usher in a new era of human exploration,” SpaceX President Gwynne Shotwell said in the Axiom statement”. https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/7/21167696/spacex-dragon-1-cargo-capsule-nasa-international-space-station-falcon-9

Based off of the available resources regarding SpaceX’s scheduled launch for this spring, I suggest there is a 78% chance that SpaceX will launch its first crewed mission into orbit before July 1, 2020. SpaceX Crew Dragon capsule arrived on Florida's Space Coast on Thursday (Feb. 13), and now Technicians can start prepping the vehicle for the launch that will kick off Demo-2, a test mission that will send NASA astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken to the International Space Station (ISS). SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule aced an in-flight abort test Sunday morning (Jan. 19), successfully jetting away from its Falcon 9 rocket less than 90 seconds after liftoff and demonstrated the spacecraft's ability to keep astronauts safe in the event of a launch emergency, marking a big step on the path toward crewed flight. In terms of the astronauts capabilities, Behnken and Hurley have been working closely with SpaceX on the Crew Dragon's development since 2015, so they're well equipped to fly the spacecraft. In total, the two astronauts have worked together for two decades. As of 17 February 2020, Falcon 9 has achieved 82 out of 84 full mission successes (97.6%), so it is sound to say they have a dependable record regarding safety and mission performance. There is still major caution around this launch, and Bridenstine was quick to add that the new timeline could slip again and that “We need more realism built in to our development time frames”, when asked how soon he the capsule would be ready to fly astronauts into orbit. He also said “We are not going to take any undue risk,” he said, standing beside Musk and the two astronauts slated to fly aboard the Crew Dragon - Doug Hurley and Bob Benkoe. Musk also noted “It’s a pretty arduous engineering job to get the parachutes right,” highlighting that Crew Dragon’s parachutes will be at least twice as safe as those used during NASA’s Apollo moon missions.

https://www.space.com/spacex-crew-dragon-astronaut-launch-by-spring-2020.html
https://www.sciencealert.com/these-are-the-first-2-astronauts-who-will-fly-on-spacex-s-historic-crew-dragon
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-exploration-spacex/nasa-aims-for-first-manned-spacex-mission-in-first-quarter-2020-idUSKBN1WP1CS
https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2020-01-19/spacex-to-try-rocket-failure-test-again-after-bad-weather-delay

As of 17 February 2020, Falcon 9 has achieved 82 out of 84 full mission successes (97.6%). According to the wiki, SpaceX will test the Flacon Heavy (based on Falcon 9)  Merlin engines prior to flight, so we will know by late April or early-May if it passes the preflight tests. My first estimate is therefore based on SpaceX's success rate. My only thought will be the non-launch related impact of Covid-19 on the launch facility staffing and space program. I would expect the crew and back up will be put into preventative isolation for up to six weeks before launch. If the launch facility is closed because of it, however, there will be no flight. Therefore the only revision to my estimate will be based on Covid-19 pervasiveness, and not Space X's ability to conduct the mission.  Of their failures, one placed the load in the wrong orbit and a second was destroyed in flight. So a small sample size, but higher reliability than any other agency at the moment, so the reality is they have a 100% launch rate and 97.6% mission success rate. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falcon_9#Reliability
